Hey,

> "Change in the genetic composition of a population
> during successive
> generations, as a result of natural selection acting
> on the genetic variation
> among individuals, and resulting in the development
> of new species."

This is probably better than the other definitions you
found, but it only mentions natural selection as an
evolutionary pressure.  If you took this definition
literally, you wouldn't say a toy poodle is a result
of evolution.

It's best to look for definitions in actual biology
texts (like Campbell's).  It's a pretty complex
concept, and most dictionaries have done a poor job
defining it.

> It's a trivial point, but is random selection still
> selection?  Is there any
> difference between not having a fitness function,
> and having a random fitness function?

I don't think it's a trivial point...I think it's a
good one.  In fact, the word "selection" is probably
an unfortunate choice, since it connotes intent.

I think the important distinction to be made is that
with natural selection, some individuals survive
because they're better suited to the
environment...there's a correlation between some
inherent property of the individual and its survival. 
But if survival is purely random, there's no
correlation between life/death and any inherent
properties of the individual.  I wouldn't call that
"selection" (since no attributes are being selected
for...I'd guess philosophers and philologists could
argue about this all day, though), and I wouldn't call
it a "fitness function" (because there's absolutely no
correlation between survival and fitness).

Derek
